description: From Middle English plot, plotte, from Old English plot (‚Äúa plot of ground‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *plataz, *platjaz (‚Äúa patch‚Äù), of uncertain origin. Cognate with Middle Low German plet (‚Äúpatch, strip of cloth, rags‚Äù), German Bletz (‚Äúrags, bits, strip of land‚Äù), Gothic êçÄêåªêå∞êçÑêçÉ (plats, ‚Äúa patch, rags‚Äù). See also plat. See also complot for an influence on or source of the "secret plan" sense.

entries.meaning: (narratology) The course of a story, comprising a series of incidents which are gradually unfolded, sometimes by unexpected means. [from 1640s]
An area or land used for building on or planting on. [from 1550s]
A graph or diagram drawn by hand or produced by a mechanical or electronic device.
examples: I was told to fly out on a vector of 100 degrees to meet a strong plot of aircraft 30 miles from the coast.

entries.meaning: A secret plan to achieve an end, the end or means usually being illegal or otherwise questionable. [from 1580s]
examples: The plot would have enabled them to get a majority on the board.
The assassination of Lincoln was part of a larger plot.

entries.meaning: Contrivance; deep reach thought; ability to plot or intrigue.
Participation in any stratagem or conspiracy.
(Various fandom slang, euphemistic) Attractive physical attributes of characters involved in a story, originating from ironic juxtaposition with the original meaning (course of the story).
examples: I'm not sure what's happening in that show, I mainly watch it for the plot.

verbs.description: plot (third-person singular simple present plots, present participle plotting, simple past and past participle plotted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To conceive (a crime, misdeed etc).
examples: They were plotting against the king.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To trace out (a graph or diagram).
examples: They plotted the number of edits per day.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To mark (a point on a graph, chart, etc).
examples: Every five minutes they plotted their position.
